header_summary:
Andrew Toth's proposal for a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) focuses on enhancing the security and reliability of silent payments through the introduction of a standard method for generating and verifying discrete logarithm equality proofs (DLEQ proofs) over the secp256k1 elliptic curve. This method is crucial for scenarios like Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH), aiming to ensure the correctness of output scripts in Partially Signed Bitcoin Transactions (PSBTs) without compromising private keys, addressing a requirement of BIP352. [Read more about this initiative](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/b0f40eab-42f3-4153-8083-b455fbd17e19n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#md54f948a215a1d828571be3122954b53fdf40b96).

Antoine Riard highlights advancements in the bitcoind build system and the development of libbitcoinkernel projects, aiming to run the bitcoin consensus engine securely within a secure enclave to minimize security threats. This effort led to the creation of a standalone repository for libbitcoinkernel, facilitating its integration into full-node implementations and opening new avenues for bitcoin node diversity and security. The project, still in its infancy, seeks feedback for improvement and is accessible at [this GitHub link](https://github.com/ariard/standalone-bitcoinkernel).

The discussion on quantum resistance in Bitcoin cryptography, led by conduition, reflects a proactive approach to addressing future challenges posed by quantum computing. It proposes a transitional strategy using hash-based signature algorithms to safeguard against quantum vulnerabilities without immediate consensus changes. This strategy, incorporating Winternitz one-time signatures, provides a pragmatic path toward future-proofing Bitcoin against quantum threats, emphasizing the importance of a flexible and forward-thinking approach to cryptographic standardization. [Read more about this proposed transitional framework](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/proposing-a-p2qrh-bip-towards-a-quantum-resistant-soft-fork/956/3).

GaloisField2718 explores the application of Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) in blockchain covenants, emphasizing the shift from off-chain to on-chain verification processes. This inquiry underlines the technical and theoretical challenges of integrating ZKPs with blockchain technology, and the ongoing exploration of their practical implementation. The discussion raises critical questions about the verification, encryption, and transmission of data within these cryptographic frameworks, pointing to a growing interest in the practical applicability of ZKPs in enhancing blockchain security and functionality. [Explore the discussion on ZKPs and blockchain covenants](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-pipes-covenants-on-bitcoin-without-soft-fork/1195/2).

recent_posts.title: BIP: DLEQ
recent_posts.summary:
- The BIP proposes a method for creating zero-knowledge proofs on Bitcoin's secp256k1 curve.
- It aims to increase PSBT security by verifying discrete logarithm equality proofs without exposing private keys.
- This standardization helps ensure the correctness of ECDH shared secrets in output scripts, preventing fund loss.

recent_posts.title: On Libbitcoinkernel Readyness
recent_posts.summary:
- Significant efforts improved bitcoind's build system and developed libbitcoinkernel projects.
- A public repository for libbitcoinkernel aims to simplify use for newcomers, enhancing documentation.
- The initiative seeks to expand bitcoin node implementation options and enhance security through isolation.

recent_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
recent_posts.summary:
- The push for quantum resistance in cryptography aims to prepare for future quantum computing threats.
- A proposed strategy for Bitcoin involves transitioning to post-quantum secure keys without immediate network consensus changes.
- The adoption of Winternitz OTS highlights a pragmatic approach to quantum uncertainties, deferring consensus changes.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin PIPEs: Covenants on Bitcoin Without Soft Fork
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses implementing Zero-Knowledge Proofs in PIPE setups and blockchain covenants.
- It questions the sequence of operations for pushing ciphertext in blockchains and conflict resolution post-transaction.
- The author is curious about the real-world application of the theoretical concepts mentioned.

active_posts.title: Signing a Bitcoin Transaction with Lamport Signatures (no changes needed)
active_posts.summary:
- An innovative approach using Lamport signatures for Bitcoin transactions was developed without OP_CAT.
- This method relies on ECDSA signature length as a proxy for transaction hashes, enhancing security.
- Despite its promise, vulnerabilities like tuning and mix and match attacks necessitate further refinements.

active_posts.title: Redefine packages to discourage address reuse
active_posts.summary:
- Address reuse in Bitcoin transactions threatens privacy, necessitating new solutions.
- Modifying mempool policy or redefining package transactions could mitigate address reuse issues.
- Implementing BIP 331's package concept may enhance privacy but introduces feasibility concerns.

active_posts.title: Proposal for Quantum-Resistant Cryptography in Bitcoin - BIP Submission
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal aims to integrate quantum-resistant cryptography, such as SPHINCS+ and Dilithium, into Bitcoin.
- It suggests modifications like a new address format and updates for quantum-resistance, ensuring backwards compatibility.
- Agustín Cruz seeks community feedback on the proposal, available for review at the provided GitHub URL.

active_posts.title: Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd
active_posts.summary:
- In March 2024, a consensus bug was discovered and fixed in btcd v0.24.2.
- Despite minor network impact, the bug posed a critical threat by allowing node hard forks.
- The authors stress upgrading to the latest version to protect against this vulnerability.

active_posts.title: OP_PAIRCOMMIT as a candidate for addition to LNhance
active_posts.summary:
- Optimizing SHA256 use in LN-Symmetry involves pre-computing the Tag to improve process efficiency.
- Potential length redistribution attacks in CTV hash commitments are addressed by altering preimage bits.
- A custom hash function using prime numbers mitigates stack element resizing attacks, enhancing security.

active_posts.title: LN Summit 2024 Notes & Summary/Commentary
active_posts.summary:
- Over thirty Lightning developers met in Tokyo to discuss Lightning and Bitcoin protocol developments.
- Key topics included Package Relay, V3 Commitments, and enhancing transaction confirmations and privacy.
- The summit focused on scalability, the Gossip protocol, BOLT 12 integration, and improving network capacity.

today_in_history_posts.title: TAPLEAF_UPDATE_VERIFY covenant opcode
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The email proposes "TAPLEAF_UPDATE_VERIFY" to update keys and scripts in Bitcoin transactions.
- Suggestion to enhance TLUV by fetching scripts from the annex for dynamic updates is discussed.
- Participants explore solutions for utxo concurrency and express optimism about Bitcoin's covenant space advancements.

today_in_history_posts.title: Removing lnd's source code from the Lightning specs repository
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new Github organization named lightning now includes all key implementation maintainers as admins.
- The blips repository was created for ongoing PRs, shifting from the lightning-rfc to "bolts."- Olaoluwa Osuntokun's proposal for an independent spec repo was approved, leading to the use of github.com/lightning/bolts.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin aims to scale by establishing 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for weekly transactions.
- These entities range from federated sidechains to time-sensitive smart contract-based coinpools.
- Key challenges include ensuring security, optimizing transaction costs, and maintaining Bitcoin's base-layer value.
